conclusion: To determine if the displacements of cars A and B are the same during the time interval from t = 0 to t = t1, we need to analyze the area under their respective velocity-time (vt) graphs.
The area under a velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the object.
The vertical axis represents velocity (v). The horizontal axis represents time (t). The curves A and B represent the velocities of Car A and Car B, respectively, over time.

premise: Displacement is the integral of velocity with respect to time, which geometrically corresponds to the area under the velocity-time graph.
conclusion: For Car A, the area under the curve from t = 0 to t = t1 is the region bounded by the curve A, the time axis, and the vertical lines at t = 0 and t = t1.

Visually, the area under curve A appears to be larger than the area under curve B within the given time interval.

Curve B starts at a lower initial velocity v1 and decreases to a final velocity that is lower than the final velocity of Car A.

premise: Since the area under curve A is greater than the area under curve B from t = 0 to t = t1.
conclusion: The displacement of Car A is greater than the displacement of Car B during this time interval.

conclusion: No, the displacements of cars A and B are not the same during the time interval from t = 0 to t = t1. Car A has a greater displacement than Car B.
